abstract.p: Highlights and lowlights from weekend college football games reviewed (S)

block.p: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.
Extended for another week LaDainian Tomlinson rushed for 243 yards on 39 carries and had two touchdowns as Texas Christian, now No. 18, defeated Northwestern, 41-14.

Michael Vick scored on a dazzling flip into the end zone, threw for a touchdown and set up a third with a 45-yard run as Virginia Tech, now No. 5, beat Rutgers, 49-0. He outgained Rutgers in the first half, 209-131.
Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.
Extended for another week LaDainian Tomlinson rushed for 243 yards on 39 carries and had two touchdowns as Texas Christian, now No. 18, defeated Northwestern, 41-14.

Michael Vick scored on a dazzling flip into the end zone, threw for a touchdown and set up a third with a 45-yard run as Virginia Tech, now No. 5, beat Rutgers, 49-0. He outgained Rutgers in the first half, 209-131.
Shelved for lack of action Drew Brees was 13 of 22 passing for 221 yards with an interception that was returned for a touchdown in No. 21 Purdue's 23-21 loss to No. 16 Notre Dame.

Understudy of the Week Stanford's freshman quarterback, Chris Lewis, replaced the injured Randy Fasani seven minutes into the game against Texas, now No. 15, and led the Cardinal to a 27-24 victory, the biggest upset of the weekend. He was 12 of 33 passing for 214 yards and 3 touchdowns, the biggest coming with 1 minute 12 seconds left in the game and Stanford trailing, 24-20. Lewis zipped a sideline pass to DeRonnie Pitts, who broke a tackle and somersaulted over Roderick Babers into the end zone.
Very Good Teams to Watch From the Hinterlands Southern Mississippi (1-1) raced to a 21-0 lead minutes into the game, forced four turnovers and handed Alabama its first shutout since 1997.

Boise State (2-1) fought back from a 31-14 deficit in the third quarter against Arkansas to tie the game in the fourth quarter. The Razorbacks scored with 6:12 to play to regain the lead at 38-31, then stopped the Broncos' bid to force overtime at their 1-yard line with about a minute to play.

History Sprouts From Ivy Yale became the first school to win 800 games as Rashad Bartholomew scored three touchdowns and rushed for 201 yards in a 42-6 victory over Dayton. Yale played its first game on Nov. 16, 1872, beating Columbia, 3-0. The Bulldogs are 800-298-51 in 128 seasons.

Who Loves You, Baby? ''One of two things is going to happen. Either we are going to separate and fall or we're going to come together. I simply have to do a better job. I love this group of guys. They deserve better than what they're getting for me.'' -- Alabama Coach Mike DuBose after losing to Southern Mississippi, 21-0, and falling to 1-2 (and out of the polls?).
